website_summaries.verdict: A fun game that progressively teaches coding principles to kids in a way that will have parents jumping in to play as well.
pros: Teaches principles of programming by showing kids how to think in sequential steps
Ages 6 and up are fascinated by the 60 challenges this game offers, which get progressively harder
Can be played solo or with others
cons: Higher levels may too too challenging for younger players
Cardboard tokens are handled a lot and can wear out quickly

customer_reviews.title: My son (10) is really good at logic games and such and had a really ...
customer_reviews.text: My son (10) is really good at logic games and such and had a really hard time figuring out the directions for this one. HE has only played it one time and does not show any interest in playing it again
customer_reviews.author: Paige D

customer_reviews.title: Fun for kids and adults!
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for my 6-year-old son. He loves working his way through the levels, but it is challenging enough that he won't get through it quickly. As a matter of fact, I am enjoying working my way through the levels too. Some are more challenging than others. I like that my son can play on his own or we can sit side-by-side and try to get them individually while spending time together. Neither he nor I are get bored with this game! I recommend it to anyone who wants to teach principles of coding without using electronics, and to anyone who loves solving puzzles (might be a tad easy for an adult experienced in puzzle-solving though).
customer_reviews.author: PuzzleBox

customer_reviews.title: Great programming game
customer_reviews.text: This is a great game that challenges all of my children (ages 5, 5, 7, and 9). We use it in a group setting where everyone has a turn and can receive help, if needed, as well as individually. I have considered purchasing three more so each child can work independently at the same time. It would be great if this company had additional puzzle books you could purchase separately.
customer_reviews.author: Terra

customer_reviews.title: Nice game for kids who like coding
customer_reviews.text: My 8 1/2 yr old son loves to code. We came across this game.... I liked the concept cuz it didn’t need a screen to use. Some peoples reviews said it’s too difficult but so far my sons done sm intermediate levels and he’s able to get through them just fine. It’s not too hard to understand once u know what all the symbols mean. He really enjoys playing it.
customer_reviews.author: M. Namso

customer_reviews.title: Great non-electronic way to practice coding
customer_reviews.text: We got this for my sons 10th birthday. He wants to learn coding and it’s a really creative way for kids to learn the concepts without them spending more time in front of screens! It gets progressively more difficult and has even been a challenge for my programmer husband. The avatar and portal are a little large for the booklet would be my only criticism. It’s got fairly easy to follow directions for how to start each puzzle and you can always look at the answer key to check your solution. We are impressed with it and would recommend it to others.
customer_reviews.author: M. Gerschutz

customer_reviews.title: Great for the mind and a nice challenge for any age
customer_reviews.text: This game is tough! I can see this being something a kid can keep playing as they grow. Or just be challenged as an adult or a young kid. You progress through levels. We found it fun and challenging. As a homeschool family we appreciate the educational value.
customer_reviews.author: Erica B

customer_reviews.title: Her Grandpa worked in IT and found it fun to get her started and watch her figure out ...
customer_reviews.text: Needed something for a 9 year old that she could work on by herself. Seemed to be hit and she quickly started to challenge herself and start solving the programming logic. Her Grandpa worked in IT and found it fun to get her started and watch her figure out the logic.
customer_reviews.author: fish&hunt

customer_reviews.title: Looks dry at first but surprisingly fun and engaging for my kid
customer_reviews.text: Incredibly intuitive, my very thoughtful, albeit advanced for his age :), five year old son has no trouble navigating through the levels. I have to be there to nudge him along with hints. I thought the game looked dry and boring at first, but it’s actually very addictive and fun for my kid. It feels like a puzzle and board game in one.
customer_reviews.author: Eileen James

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: My third grade students enjoy playing this game. We've used it to introduce coding logic.
customer_reviews.author: Juliette Bettencourt

customer_reviews.title: Winner for 8 Year Old!
customer_reviews.text: This was a gift for a granddaughter and the whole family loves working together on the projects!
customer_reviews.author: Caterwaul

customer_reviews.title: Great game, either map is too small or pieces are too big.
customer_reviews.text: The game itself is a lot of fun for my 7 year old. We really enjoy the ThinkFun games. That being said the pieces for the avatar and portal at too big for the maps. On the picture you can see how the avatar covers a small red loop which is needed to beat the level.
customer_reviews.author: Super Amazonish Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good game for one person
customer_reviews.text: Fun game to play however it is only for 1 player. I take turns playing it with my son (college age) and we've gotten to the higher levels. It's still challenging even for adults, but the only way to play with another person is to have 1 person do a level, then the other person does the next level, or else see you can solve it first. It really isn't something you can easily just do with someone else. I am a teacher and I could also see putting the playing board projected for the class and having kids work in teams. That's actually probably the best option for kids.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Birthday Gift - Arrived Late & Damaged
customer_reviews.text: I purchased the ThinkFun Programming Game as a gift for my nephew. The package arrived late, luckily it was the day of the birthday party. When I opened the envelope (they did not use a box) this package came in I found the game box damaged, the cellophane was ripped and the box corner destroyed. Being that it was the day of the party I decided to gift the damaged item to my nephew rather than return it.
customer_reviews.author: SamR.

customer_reviews.title: My grandson likes this if an adult plays with him ...
customer_reviews.text: My grandson likes this if an adult plays with him, but he won’t pick it up on his own.
customer_reviews.author: C. King

customer_reviews.title: Kinda fun.
customer_reviews.text: My grand kids ages 8 & 10 played with it off & on for a few days. Then it got old. On the plus side, they have retained what they learned so in that aspect it was worth the $.
customer_reviews.author: ZeeKid

customer_reviews.title: Great fun.
customer_reviews.text: Gave as a gift for my 10-year-old son. It does a great job of teaching the logic needed and presents it a series of puzzles that get increasingly harder. My son is still working through the beginner series, but is doing so without my help, and he's having fun, which is most important. I am not a computer whiz or coder myself, but I enjoy the puzzle aspect. It will be interesting to see how the more difficult levels teach the computing concepts of programming.
customer_reviews.author: gamegirl

customer_reviews.title: Great intro to coding for all ages
customer_reviews.text: Game is great for players of all levels - from my 9 year old son to my 38 year old husband. Honestly, I think the 9 year old picked it up faster.
customer_reviews.author: lexibelle

customer_reviews.title: Great fun
customer_reviews.text: Great for my students who like a challenge but can’t get it in the classroom by playing a game.

customer_reviews.title: For really brainy kids I guess
customer_reviews.text: Too difficult. We couldn't get past the first two pages.

customer_reviews.title: It's not too easy and not too hard
customer_reviews.text: My 8yo son loves this game. He plays it every morning before we start school. It's not too easy and not too hard. I like that it has a lot of levels so it's going to last for a while.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: A good critical thinking skill building game.
customer_reviews.text: Great innovative game for my 7 year old. I really like that it can be played solo or with a partner. Easy to get started. My son has become frustrated at a certain level, so it is on hold for now, but I believe he'll come back to it. He likes to play it before we wake up in the morning- a good critical thinking skill building game.

customer_reviews.title: Great gift
customer_reviews.text: Grandson loves electronics and mind challenges. I'm sure he'll love this
customer_reviews.author: Pattie

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic game. Challenging without being frustrating. My students love this station during STEM time. I confess, I like playing too. Just bought one for my nephew for Christmas. Can’t wait to play with him.
customer_reviews.author: Mom / Teacher

customer_reviews.title: Fun logic game
customer_reviews.text: Anything that can occupy my 7-years old for hours is a champion. Got this game 3 days ago and he has completed 40+ levels. This game is not really about programming or coding but about logic. Fun nevertheless.
customer_reviews.author: Lucas1

customer_reviews.title: A birthday gift.

customer_reviews.title: I love this

customer_reviews.title: All of the Think Fun games we gave him are still in use
customer_reviews.text: My 9 year old son loves this game. It did take him a few minutes to understand it, but once he did it was all he wanted to play. We gave it to him for Christmas, and he still plays it regularly. All of the Think Fun games we gave him are still in use. I highly recommend!
customer_reviews.author: M. Chatterton

customer_reviews.title: great game!
customer_reviews.text: Great game with great design! My kid likes it very much!
customer_reviews.author: yujie

customer_reviews.title: awesome game- small flaw in piece design (see review)
customer_reviews.text: The ONLY reason I gave this 4 stars is because the portal and character pieces are often too big and obscure parts of the puzzle. It's annoying and a bit of an inconvenience, but you can either just a) ignore it or b) use other figurines that are smaller. The actual game itself is absolutely awesome- very challenging, very fun. It ramps up in difficulty very smoothly- and my 6 year old was able to play it no problem. So that's my only recommendation to thinkfun if they ever create a 2.0 version of this game- please make the plastic pieces a bit narrower so that the gameplay area isn't obstructed. :)
customer_reviews.author: solidwhetstone

customer_reviews.title: Challenging and fun
customer_reviews.text: It's a fun game that my 10yr old loves. It's mentally stimulating Basically your game piece has to travel around the board looking for crystals. You have to use programming logic to help collect those crystals. You have to really think because there is only 1 sequence of actions that will be successful. It makes my kids think and challenges them, which I LOVE!!
customer_reviews.author: Beeswax

customer_reviews.title: code master programming logic game
customer_reviews.text: my 18 year old likes this game but states it is definitely a game for the house and not something you could do while traveling. the levels are challenging but not frustrating
customer_reviews.author: S. Winn

customer_reviews.title: 6 yr old dominates this game
customer_reviews.text: My 6 year old son got to level 7 writhing 5 minutes. It really teaches then how coding works. The harder levels introduce them to multiple steps and patterns
customer_reviews.author: Somertime

customer_reviews.title: This game is an amazing logic game
customer_reviews.text: I bought this game to use with a Coding Club with 3rd-5th graders. This game is an amazing logic game. It starts easy and gets pretty difficult. I wish there were some hints or a little more direction when kids get stuck. My students like to work together on the levels--like future programmers.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Very well designed.
customer_reviews.text: Great game. My 8 year old and I had so much fun solving the puzzles. We did all of them over a period of one year. I am a software engineer and I can appreciate how well this game is designed.
customer_reviews.author: Konstantine

customer_reviews.title: Love it! And so do my 3 boys.
customer_reviews.text: bought t my 9 year old boy's birthday. He is intelligent, and borderline ADD, so we have been looking for something to challenge him and to discover his "intellectual niche". This game was it. At first, reading the instructions, I thought, "This is way to complicated for him to follow". But once we started, he got very interested and involved. I also have a 7 and an 11 year old boys, and they too were very interested in the game. When my wife came home, the boys were excited to show her, and she played it and could not stop. Well, well, well worth the $20. PLUS: It's educational!

customer_reviews.text: This looked like a fun game and I was looking forward to opening it with my 10 year old on Christmas. The disappointment that happened when we opened the box and there were no maps... Basically the playing board without which you cannot play the game. Now I have to jump through hoops to try to get the maps. I'm not happy with the quality control or the effort I now have to expend to get the missing maps. I'll have to update when/if I get them.

We have great conversations while playing the game and he even has changed the story to be kid trying to reach mother instead of avatar reaching portal.

It is easy to figure out, without a ton of directions (so it kept his interest right off the bat), but it gets challenging so it can keep him entertained for a while.

product_meta.title: ThinkFun Code Master Programming Logic Game and STEM Toy – Teaches Programming Skills Through Fun Gameplay
product_meta.description: Code Master is one of ThinkFun's best stem toys for boys and girls, and winner of several awards. In Code Master, your avatar travels to an exotic world in search of power crystals. Along the way, you use programming logic to navigate the map. Think carefully, in each level, only one specific sequence of actions will lead to success. Once you collect all the crystals and land at the portal, you win! This STEM toy for boys and girls won’t just teach you principles behind programming, you’ll also build planning, sequential reasoning and problem-solving skills. Code Master is one of the best gifts you can buy for kids who like smart games and a challenge. It's made with high quality components, and comes with a very clear and easy to understand instruction manual - you'll be able to play within minutes of opening the box.
feature_bullets: Trusted by Families Worldwide - With over 50 million sold, ThinkFun is the world's leader in brain and logic games.
Develops critical skills – Playing through the challenges builds reasoning and planning skills and provides a great stealth learning experience for young players.

What you get – Code Master is the ultimate coding board game and STEM toy, and teaches programming logic through fun gameplay. Contains 10 maps with 60 levels to solve, as well as 12 guide scrolls, 12 action tokens, 8 conditional tokens, and an instruction booklet with solutions included. Makes a great gift for smart kids ages 8 and up.
Clear instructions – Easy to learn with a clear, high quality instruction manual. You can start playing immediately!
Comes with multi-level challenges - Code Master comes with 60 beginner to expert challenges that become increasingly difficult as you play through them.

specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.5 out of 5 stars346 ratings4.5 out of 5 stars
